I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to Armenia for additional financing for the Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Project.1  
 
2.  The additional financing will (i) rehabilitate and upgrade water supply infrastructure, (ii) 
improve the performance of water services, and (iii) improve the management and operational 
efficiency of the water utility company.2 Also, the additional financing will ensure further public 
health  and  environmental  improvements  by  providing  potable  and  reliable  water  supply  to 
households in approximately 18 towns and 92 villages in the provinces of Aragatsotn, Ararat, 
Amavir,  Geharqunik,  Tavush,  Lori,  Kotayq,  Shirak,  Syunik,  and  Vayotz-Dzor.  The  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  loan  will  form  part  of  a  larger  sector  capital  investment  by  the 
government of Armenia and other international financial institutions including the World Bank 
and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  The government has been systemically facilitating improvements in the water supply and 
sanitation (WSS) sector through significant legislative and institutional reforms, notably the 
adoption of (i) the Water Code of Armenia in 2002 to promote water allocation based on water 
resource supply, (ii) the Law on Fundamental Provisions of the National Water Policy in 2005 for 
the strategic use and protection of water resources and systems, and (iii) the National Water 
Program in 2006 to address water resource formation and sustainability. 
 
4.  In October 2007, ADB approved funding for the Water Supply and Sanitation Sector 
Project to upgrade and rehabilitate WSS systems in 18 subprojects  in 16 towns and 125 
villages.3 The  current  project  had  two  components:  (i)  infrastructure  rehabilitation,  and  (ii) 
improvements in management and operational efficiency. The current project is expected to be 
completed in the first quarter of 2012, which is 12 months ahead of schedule. 
 
5.  Foreseeing the likely success of the current project, the government has requested 
through the State Committee for Water Economy (SCWE) that ADB further fund the additional 
financing  and  support  the  government’s  continued  efforts  to  rehabilitate  and  extend  WSS 
systems with an additional 10 subprojects and further improve the operational efficiency and 
financial management of the Armenia Water and Sewerage Company (AWSC), a government-
owned  commercial  company  that  Société  d'Aménagement  Urbain  et  Rural  (SAUR),  an 
international water utility, manages and operates through a management contract. 
 
6.  The  additional  financing  is  included  in  the  country  operational  business  plan4 and 
strongly supports the government’s objective of facilitating human development through better 
access to reliable and sustainable supplies of potable water, improving living conditions in 
approximately 18 towns and 92 villages in Armenia.

Republic of Armenia for the Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Project. Manila (Loan 2363-ARM, for $36 million, 
approved on 31 October).

B.  Progress and Performance of the Current Project 
 
7.  Project performance. The progress and implementation of the current project is on 
track. The AWSC has effectively managed and coordinated the various contract packages for 
the current project and the overall operation of the company. The recent progress report5 by 
AWSC and by ADB6 report the current project having delivered the key results discussed below. 
 
8.  Component A. Construction completion is 12 months ahead of schedule.7 More towns 
have been covered which resulted in 24,000 additional beneficiaries with safe and reliable 
water. Water supply and sewerage systems in 21 towns and 97 villages were rehabilitated or 
replaced. In terms of outcomes in the design and monitoring framework, the current project has 
improved access to reliable supplies of potable water for 600,000 people, which exceeds the 
baseline target of 576,000 people. 
 
9.  All 40 civil works contracts have been awarded, with 33 completed and the remainder 
either ongoing or close to completion. The project had disbursed $33 million of its $36 million as 
of the third quarter of 2011. More than 450 kilometers of water pipes and 17,500 water meters 
were installed from 2008 to 2010. The number of consumers receiving 24-hour water supply 
increased by 46% from 2008 to 2010.8 
 
10.  Component B. Improvements in service delivery are reflected in public satisfaction rates 
rising to 66% in 2010 from 42% in 2008. Tariff collection significantly increased from 61% in 
2008  to  74%  in  2010.  Financial  management  improved  through  the  introduction  of  new 
accounting procedures, a computerized billing and collection system, and a system of mapping 
asset inventories. These results meet project targets as set out in outputs 3 and 4 of the design 
and monitoring framework with regard to improvements in AWSC’s operational capacity and 
community management. The exception is nonrevenue water, which has not improved during 
implementation. 
 
11.  Environment  and  social  safeguards  compliance.  All  subprojects  for  the  current 
project  have  been  prepared,  appraised,  and  implemented  in  accordance  with  the  agreed 
environmental assessment and review procedure. The AWSC has screened each approved 
subproject  for  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  effects.  No  indigenous  people  have  been 
affected or involved in any of the subprojects. 
 
12.  Management  of  risks.  Risks  identified  at  appraisal  have,  for  the  most  part,  been 
managed appropriately and so far none has affected project implementation. Anticipated delays 
caused by procurement issues did not materialize. The AWSC project team received detailed 
orientation  on  ADB’s  Procurement Guidelines (2010,  as  amended from time  to time),  and 
advance procurement facilitated the early engagement of potential contractors. 
 
13.  During current project implementation, public outreach increased community awareness 
of project effects and benefits, which improved community involvement and support for the 
current project.

14.  However, further action is needed with regard to tariff reform. A recent assessment9 by 
the World Bank suggests that the existing tariff is sufficient to cover only the costs of operation 
and emergency and routine maintenance but not of preventative maintenance, replacement, 
and system expansion. Tariff reform is a provision under the ADB loan for the current project. 
Tariff reform is critical to the long-term financial viability of water operators, so a tariff plan10 has 
been included as a loan provision under additional financing. 
 
C.  Project’s Eligibility for Additional Financing 
 
15.  The additional financing meets the eligibility criteria in ADB’s additional financing policy11 
because the overall project remains technically feasible, economically viable, and financially 
sound. The government accords the additional financing high priority, and it is consistent with 
the overall project’s development objectives and the current country operations and business 
plan (footnote 4). 
 
16.  Additional financing will support the continuation of the current project to the next phase 
and expand outcomes to benefit more households living in 8 additional project towns12 and 
approximately 63 additional project villages in Armenia through better access to water supply 
that is safe, reliable, and sustainable. 
 
D.  Impact and Outcome 
 
17.  The overall project’s revised impact and outcome will expand project benefits in terms of 
infrastructure rehabilitation, water service improvements, and operational efficiency and improve 
public health and the environment in 29 towns and 160 villages, which includes 8 towns and 63 
villages13 not  covered  by the  current  project,  through  safe, reliable,  and  sustainable  water 
supply.  The  government  is  expected  to  continue  to  implement  institutional  and  legislative 
reforms to help the AWSC enhance its management capacity and operational efficiency. 
 
18.  The  overall  project  will  reduce  poverty  by  (i) reducing  the  incidence of  waterborne 
disease and cost of medical care, (ii) allowing women to spend less time collecting water and 
more time participating in social and economic activities, (iii) providing safer and more reliable 
water supply, and (iv) improving the quality of life in all project towns and villages. 
 
E.  Outputs 
 
19.  As with the current project, the additional financing will (i) rehabilitate and upgrade water 
supply  infrastructure,  (ii)  improve  the  performance  of  water  services,  and  (iii)  improve  the 
management and operational efficiency of the water utility company. 
 
20.  Municipal  infrastructure  rehabilitation  and  improvement. This will rehabilitate or 
replace  existing  water  supply  infrastructure.  Works  will  include  the  construction  of  600 
kilometers of new mains and pipe networks to connect 110,000 new and existing customers; the 
rehabilitation of about 5 pumping stations, about 3 chlorination stations, 1 water treatment plant, 
and about 15 daily regulation reservoirs; and the installation of water meters on the premises of

supply systems. 
 
 21.  Management improvement and capacity development. This will further improve the 
operational and management efficiency of the AWSC by (i) increasing public awareness of 
municipal infrastructure rehabilitation and improvement through public awareness and media 
campaigns, (ii) strengthening service contracts between the AWSC and municipal governments 
governing  the  use  of  locally  owned  distribution  networks  and  the  contracts  between  the 
company and communities taking bulk water supply, (iii) developing a disconnection policy for 
nonpayers, and (iv) preparing a strategy to develop the AWSC’s human resources by improving 
staff training and development.

the same terms and conditions as the ADB loan. The AWSC will service the loan and bear the

G.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
25.  Project management. The SCWE will again be the executing agency for the additional 
financing,  coordinate  implementation,  and  establish  the  project  coordination  unit,  which  is 
expected to be the same unit as for the current project, consisting of two staffers: a project 
coordinator and an administrative assistant. The project coordination unit will coordinate closely 
with ADB, the project management unit (PMU), and government agencies. The AWSC will again 
be the implementing agency and coordinate additional financing implementation with the PMU. 
It is expected that the PMU under the current project will take on the same responsibilities for 
the additional financing with a staff of about 14. The PMU will be headed by a project manager 
and  staffed  by  an  engineer  and/or  technical  specialist,  a  social  safeguard  specialist,  a 
procurement specialist, a finance and accounting specialist, and support staff. 
 
26.  Implementation  period. The additional financing will be implemented over 5 years 
commencing in May 2012. The implementation of the current project was also 5 years, but the 
strong performance of the AWSC has the current project now scheduled for completion 12 
months ahead of schedule. 
 
27.  Management  contract.  The  AWSC  is  currently  managed  and  operated  under  a 
management contract with SAUR, a private international provider of water and wastewater 
services. The management contract with SAUR was recently extended for an additional 2 years 
to the end of 2013. 
 
28.  Advance  contracting  and  retroactive  financing.  To  facilitate  additional  financing 
preparation,  the  AWSC  has  requested  advance  contracting  and  retroactive  financing  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time)  with  respect  to  consulting  packages  for  technical  design,  construction  supervision, 
capacity  building,  and  public  awareness  campaigns.  Any  concurrence  by  ADB  regarding 
procedures, documentation, or proposals for awarding contract does not commit ADB to finance 
any such additional financing expenditures. 
 
29.  Procurement. Procurement financed under the additional financing will accord with ADB 
Procurement Guidelines. The procurement plan is in the project administration manual.14 
 
                                                
14 Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

30.  Disbursement  arrangements. Loan proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with 
ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook (2007, as amended from time to time). The PMU in the 
AWSC,  as  implementing  agency,  will  establish,  maintain,  and  manage  a  separate  imprest 
account  after  loan  effectiveness.  The  advance  under  the  imprest  account  will  not  exceed 
estimated eligible expenditures for the next 6 months, or 10% of the loan amount, whichever is 
lower. The statement of expenditures procedure may be used to reimburse eligible expenditures 
and liquidate the advance into the imprest account; any individual payment to be reimbursed or 
liquidated under the procedure will not exceed the equivalent of $100,000. 
 
31.  Project performance management and evaluation. As with the current project, a list 
of  performance  indicators  will  be  tracked  and  evaluated  under  a  project  performance 
management system. The project performance management system will monitor and track the 
technical  performance  of  the  additional  financing  and,  at  the  same  time,  the  additional 
financing’s  social,  gender,  and  economic  benefits,  in  particular  for  the  poor  and  women. 
Baseline data and performance targets will have to be established at project commencement, 
and performance indicators will be monitored and reported to ADB through quarterly progress 
reports. 
 
32.  Project review. Review missions will be undertaken twice a year in the first 2 years and 
thereafter once a year. The review will evaluate the scope, implementation arrangements, and 
performance of additional financing components. A staff consultant may be required for project 
reviews. 
 
33.  Subproject  selection,  preparation,  and  appraisal.  Subprojects  will  be  selected 
similarly as for the current project, following these basic criteria: (i) The subproject is consistent 
with the government’s sector policies, development objectives, and development strategy. (ii) 
The existing water supply network and equipment are dilapidated, broken down, and operating 
inefficiently, causing water supply shortages and environmental problems. (iii) The subproject is 
technically feasible and economically and financially viable. (iv) It complies with ADB safeguard 
policies and has no significant  adverse social and/or environmental impacts. (v) It can be 
completed within the additional financing implementation period.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical  
 
34.  A preliminary technical assessment has been undertaken by AWSC in-house technical 
experts and engineers using the same framework as in the detailed design assessment for the 
current project. Six subprojects representative of the 10 subprojects in the additional financing 
were assessed through (i) a survey of the existing water supply system, (ii) an assessment of 
population growth and likely future water demand in project towns and villages, (iii) a preliminary 
water supply network design, and (iv) a development and investment program for water supply 
system improvements. 
 
35.  The assessment highlights the deteriorating state of the water supply systems and the 
need  to  replace  and  upgrade  corroding  cast  iron  pipes  delivering  non-potable  water  to 
communities in project towns and villages. The survey noted several illegal connections to 
mains that cause inefficiencies and system losses. 
 
36.  ADB has engaged an independent water engineer to assess the validity of  project 
assumptions and the viability of the additional financing. The review noted that assumptions in 
the assessment were reasonable and that contingency arrangements are sufficient to cover any 
unplanned works. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
37.  Following ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects,15 the financial and 
economic analyses of the expanded project assess the economic viability of individual outputs 
and of the additional financing and further indicate appropriate tariffs to ensure fair returns on 
capital and cover operating costs. To determine economic viability, benefits and costs streams 
have been evaluated with and without the project, allowing estimates of incremental cash flows 
for each output and their switching values to ascertain robustness. 
 
38.  Economic analyses of the three sample subprojects were undertaken as representative 
of the 10 subprojects in the additional financing. The major economic benefits are cost savings 
on non-incremental supply to user households, previously connected and not, and the average 
demand  price  for  incremental  water  supplies  based  on  user  willingness  to  pay.  The  non-
incremental benefits are quantified using cost savings from (i) the use of alternative water 
sources; (ii) time saved not collecting water; (iii) non-technical losses; and (iv) savings on 
                                                
15 ADB. 2007. Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. Manila.

8 
operation, maintenance, and storage. Incremental benefits are valued using willingness to pay 
for service improvement. Time saved not collecting water and willingness to pay are based on 
household surveys regularly updated by the AWSC and on actual sampling interviews with 
existing and potential beneficiaries. All of the above were quantified in economic terms. Health 
impacts that accrue only after several years of system operation were not quantified. The 
analysis shows the three sample subprojects to be economically viable, with the economic 
internal rate of return  at 21.0% for the subproject  in Ararat, 19.2% in Lori, and 17.6% in 
Geharqunik, all exceeding the economic opportunity cost of capital of 12%. 
 
39.  Financial analysis assesses the capacity of subprojects to cover future costs for capital 
investments, operation, maintenance, and replacement. Analysis with and without the project 
assessed costs and revenues over 25 years. The key financial parameters of sustainability 
applied in the analysis were (i) the financial internal rate of return (FIRR), which should be 
higher than the weighted average cost of capital; (ii) tariff affordability, generally acceptable at 
up to 5% of average household income; and (iii) positive year-end cash balances. 
 
40.  The results show that the FIRRs for the samples exceed the weighted average cost of 
capital, estimated at 2.1%, with the subproject in Ararat at 6.5%, Lori at 6.3%, and Geharqunik 
at 4.9%. To assess the sensitivity of the investment to changes in anticipated benefits and/or 
costs, switching values have been calculated. The FIRRs for individual subprojects range from 
3.1% to 3.3%, showing that project components are financially viable if the proposed water 
tariffs  are  applied,  along  with  corresponding  government  subsidies  where  needed.  The 
switching values suggest that the estimates are robust  enough to absorb reasonable cost 
overruns, unanticipated decreases in revenue, and delays in project implementation. 
 
C.  Governance 
 
41.  In  the  current  project,  it  was  assessed  that  the  executing  agency  and  the  key 
implementing agency both satisfy ADB’s financial management requirements and have the 
capacity to manage procurement, which the latest assessment suggests still holds true. Both 
have satisfactory financial management capability to (i) record required financial transactions 
and balances, (ii) provide regular and reliable financial statements and monitoring reports, (iii) 
safeguard the financial assets, and (iv) subject the required financial documents to auditing 
acceptable to ADB. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to 
and discussed with the government and the SCWE. The specific policy requirements and 
supplementary measures are described in the project administration manual (footnote 14). 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
42.  Residents of approximately 18 towns and 92 villages, the majority in rural areas, will 
benefit  from  improved  water  supply  service,  among  them  the  poor  and  socially  excluded. 
Customers  in  rural  areas  strongly  support  the  additional  financing,  which  will  significantly 
improve their living standards and create new employment. The additional financing will improve 
water-use, hygiene, and sanitation in targeted areas, and will include men and women as 
informed consumers monitoring service quality. At an institutional level, women will benefit from 
improved  employment  and  career  opportunities.  A  gender  action  plan16 includes  gender-
sensitive outreach campaigns especially targeting women to inform them about their customer 
                                                
16 Phase 1 did not have a gender action plan, but phase 2 will promote effective gender mainstreaming.

9 
rights, efficient water use, hygiene and sanitation issues, and how they can claim reliable WSS 
services.17 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
43.  Environment. The additional financing is environmental category B, as its subprojects 
will not have significant irreversible or permanent negative environmental impacts during or after 
construction. According to ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the subprojects require 
initial environmental examinations (IEEs). As the scale of each operation is small and their 
impacts will be similar, one framework IEE has been prepared for the entire operation. The 
checklist provided in the framework IEE shows that site-specific environmental management 
plans (SSEMPs) for each subproject location will be prepared to address all location-specific 
impacts. The impacts likely to arise from such operations as studied in the IEE are largely 
limited to construction and can be adequately addressed through the well-designed mitigation 
recommended  in  the  report  and  further  described  in  the  SSEMPs.  The  SSEMPs  will  be 
prepared by DSC consultants and reviewed by the environment specialist in the AWSC.  Public 
consultations were held in 10 towns, and each session was attended by groups representing all 
neighboring villages. The IEE was uploaded on ADB’s website on 18 January 2012. 
 
44.  Land acquisition and resettlement. The additional financing is category B (limited 
impacts)  on  involuntary  land  acquisition  and  resettlement.  The  preliminary  design  shows 
rehabilitation and construction conducted mostly on property owned by the AWSC, on municipal 
land,  or  within  the  rights-of-way  assigned  to  municipal  infrastructure.  Limited  involuntary 
resettlement is envisaged in the removal of moveable assets (i.e., trees and crops) or restricted 
access to communal lands with its reallocation into a hydraulic facility. A sample resettlement 
plan for one of the subprojects has been prepared. Involuntary resettlement due diligence was 
conducted for the remaining subprojects. Any subsequent subprojects that would require the 
acquisition of private lands will be ineligible for financing under the additional financing. The 
approved resettlement framework of the current project was reviewed and updated for the 
additional financing. The changes in the updated resettlement framework are (i) replacing ADB’s 
Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995) with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement, (ii) restrictions 
to subprojects involving the acquisition of private property or causing significant involuntary 
resettlement, (iii) the provision of land donation procedures following ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement requirements on negotiated land acquisition, and (iv) the addition of a few regulations 
relevant to land acquisition and resettlement. The AWSC has dedicated personnel who look 
after safeguard implementation. The sample resettlement plan and the resettlement framework 
were endorsed by the SCWE and uploaded on ADB’s website on 19 December 2011. 
 
45.  Indigenous peoples. The additional financing is category C (no impact) for indigenous 
peoples. Most people in project areas are ethnic Armenian. A few ethnic or social minorities 
were identified but are fully integrated into the majority population. Public consultations were 
conducted for six subprojects. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
46.  Potential risks associated with the additional financing are (i) implementation delays 
caused by the poor performance of civil works contractors, (ii) management and operational 
capacity  reform  by  AWSC  bringing  only  slow  improvement,  (iii)  regulatory  reforms  by  the 
government such as on pricing bringing only slow improvement, and (iv) the lack of community

10 
support for the imposition of reforms by the AWSC. Measures to mitigate project risks are (i) 
using experience acquired during the current project to identify and manage suitably qualified 
contractors,  (ii)  ADB  closely  coordinating  with  the  AWSC  on  project  implementation,  (iii) 
facilitating a more coordinated policy dialogue between various development partners including 
ADB and the government, and (iv) maintaining and extending public outreach programs to new 
subproject towns and villages to gain community support for the additional financing.18 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
 
47.  The government and the SCWS have assured ADB that implementation of the additional 
financing shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption 
measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as 
described in detail in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
 
48.  The government and the AWSC have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the 
additional financing, which are set forth in the loan agreement and the project agreement. As a 
condition  to the  effectiveness  of the  loan  agreement,  a relending  agreement,  in form  and 
substance satisfactory to ADB, shall have been duly authorized and delivered on behalf of the 
government and the AWSC and shall have become fully effective and binding upon  such 
parties. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
49.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the Board 
approve  the  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to  SDR25,886,000  to  Armenia  for  the 
additional financing of the Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Project, from ADB’s Special 
Funds resources, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period 
and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and 
such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the 
draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board.
